{{Cleanup|article|
''Missing several mats such as LC05 and the five BP03 mats; also missing proper LC02/LC04 images''}} A '''playmat''' or '''game mat''', also known as a '''Duel Field''' (デュエルフィールド ''Deyuerufīrudo'') is a flat material where a player can place their cards while [[Duel]]ing. They often feature the artwork of a card (usually a [[Monster Card]]) or multiple cards, with many also labeling the official Card Zones for the [[Yu-Gi-Oh! Trading Card Game|''Yu-Gi-Oh!'' Trading Card Game]]. Most mats are mass-produced, but some are only awarded to competitors and winners of various tournament events, making them very exclusive and highly valuable items. ==In other languages== {{In other languages | fr_name = Tapis de Jeu | de_name = Spielunterlage | it_name = Tappetino da Gioco | pt_name = Tapete de Duelo | es_name = Tapete de Juego | ja_name = デュエルフィールド | ja_romaji = Deyuerufīrudo | ja_trans = Duel Field | ko_name = 듀얼 필드 | ko_rr = Dyueol Pildeu | ko_trans = Duel Field | zh_name = 決鬥枱墊 | zh_pinyin = Juédòu Tái Diàn | zh_trans = Duel Mat }} ==TCG Playmats== ===Championships=== ====Regional Qualifiers==== Mat-RegionalQualifier-Classic.jpg | Classic Mat-RegionalQualifier-SacredBeasts.png | 2007 National Qualifying season (2006-2007 Regionals): [[Sacred Beast]]s Mat-RegionalQualifier-RainbowDragon.png | [[TAEV]] Regional season: "[[Rainbow Dragon]]" Mat-RegionalQualifier-ChaosNeos.png | [[GLAS]] Regional season: "[[Elemental HERO Chaos Neos]]" Mat-RegionalQualifier-ArmageddonKnight.png | [[PTDN]] Regional season (2008 Spring Regionals): "[[Armageddon Knight]]" Mat-RegionalQualifier-JudgmentDragon.jpg | [[LODT]] Regional season (2008 Summer Regionals): "[[Judgment Dragon]]" Mat-RegionalQualifier-MontageDragon.jpg | [[TDGS]] Regional season (2008 Fall Regionals): "[[Montage Dragon]]" Mat-RegionalQualifier-Gorz.jpg | [[CSOC]] Regional season (2009 Winter Regionals): "[[Gorz the Emissary of Darkness]]" Mat-RegionalQualifier-DarkVoltanis.jpg | [[CRMS]] Regional season (2009 Regionals): "[[Dark Voltanis]]"

Tournament==== This tournament is an event where Duelists can play a Deck based off of one of the five different anime series (eras) of ''Yu-Gi-Oh!''. After all Swiss rounds for the tournament are completed, Duelists that are ranked 1st through 4th place will receive a Generation Game Mat that corresponds to the era of their Deck.[http://www.yugioh-card.com/en/events/generationduel.html Generation Duel Tournament] Mat-GDT-DM.png | ''Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters'' era: [[Yami Marik]], [[Yami Yugi]], & [[Seto Kaiba]] Mat-GDT-GX.png | ''Yu-Gi-Oh! GX'' era: [[Aster Phoenix]], [[Jesse Anderson]], [[Zane Truesdale]], [[Chazz Princeton]], & [[Jaden Yuki]] Mat-GDT-5D.png | ''Yu-Gi-Oh! 5D's'' era: [[Yusei Fudo]], [[Jack Atlas]], [[Crow Hogan]], [[Akiza Izinski]], [[Leo]], & [[Luna]] Mat-GDT-ZX.png | ''Yu-Gi-Oh! Mat-LLDS-OldEntityHastorr.png | Stage 1 Qualifiers and Stage 1 Grand Qualifiers: "[[Old Entity Hastorr]]"
Awarded exclusively to the winners of Stage 1 Qualifiers, as well as to the highest-placed Duelists in Stage 1 Grand Qualifiers. Mat-LLDS-ElderEntityNorden.png | Stage 2 Finals: "[[Elder Entity Norden]]"
Awarded to those who reach the Top Cut Playoffs (number of playmats dependent on region). Mat-LLDS-MagicianNavigation.png | Stage 1 Qualifiers: "[[Magician Navigation]]" Mat-LLDS-TheHiddenCity.png | Stage 2 Qualifiers: "[[The Hidden City]]" ====Ultimate Duelist Series (UDS)==== A tournament series that rewards Duelists who regularly participate in Organized Play programs. Duelists who manage to earn enough UDS points can enter the Ultimate Duelist Invitational for the opportunity to prove themselves as the Ultimate Duelist. Mat-UDS-MirrorForceDragon.png | Ultimate Duelist Invitational: "[[Mirror Force Dragon]]"
Awarded to those who reach the Top Cut Playoffs. ===Decks=== ====Starter Deck==== Mat-StarterDeck-Yuya.png | ''[[Starter Deck: Yuya]]'' ====Structure Deck==== [[Structure Deck]] playmats feature the cover card's artwork with the Structure Deck's name on the front. Due to the artwork, the card zones are less visible. '''Akira Samejima''' is a character in ''[[Yu-Gi-Oh! ARC-V]]'' and is a student of [[Leo Institute of Dueling]]. Their name appears when Tate goes to look up [[Dipper O'rion|Dipper]]'s profile.

==Etymology==
"Akira" is a common Japanese given name, usually male, but it can be a female name as well.

==Duels==
According to Akira's profile, they had competed in fifty-two Duels, of which they won thirty-two and lost twenty.<ref name="ep8">{{episode|Yu-Gi-Oh! ARC-V|8|ref}}</ref>

revisions.content:
[[File:Ryozanpaku School.png|thumb|right|300px|Bandit Warrior Academy]]
'''Bandit Warrior Academy''', known as '''Ryozanpaku School''' ({{Ruby|梁|りょう}}{{Ruby|山|ざん}}{{Ruby|泊|ぱく}}{{Ruby|塾|じゅく}} ''Ryōzanpaku Juku'') in the Japanese version, is a preparatory Duel school and is located in [[Paradise City]]. Its owner is [[Ryozan Godagawa]].

==Curriculum==
Bandit Warrior Academy has an extremely forceful, martial arts-style training regime. Students are taught that victory is all that matters and that Dueling and smiles do not mix. They are not allowed to go outside except to attend classes, nor permitted to see their parents until they become pros. It is said that when it comes to creating pro Duelists, Bandit Warrior Academy is second only to [[Leo Institute of Dueling]].

[[File:Ryozanpaku School training.png|thumb|left|200px|Bandit Warrior Academy's harsh training program.]]
The rather questionable and violent practices performed by the school are so infamous that the public tends to avoid proximity with them. Despite this, the school is not short on applicants.<ref name="ep39">{{episode|Yu-Gi-Oh! ARC-V|39|ref}}</ref>

After the previous edition of the [[Arc League Championship]] where [[Iggy Arlo]] ended as a runner-up, Bandit Warrior Academy acquired [[Fusion Summon]]ing and started teaching it to all of its students.<ref name="ep39" /><ref name="ep42">{{episode|Yu-Gi-Oh! ARC-V|42|ref}}</ref>

When Yuya Dueled students from the school, they knocked him away from [[Action Cards]] or nearly caused him harm from the [[ARC System]] Fields, such as when Nagi and Taka nearly caused him to fall in lava in the [[Quartet of Quandry]] Action Field.

==Etymology==
The Japanese name of the school, "''Ryozanpaku''", comes from [[wikipedia:Mount Liang|Mount Liang]], a mountain in China. It is well known as the stronghold of the 108 legendary Song Dynasty heroes (or Bandit Warriors) of the classic Chinese novel Water Margin.

==List of students==
* [[Iggy Arlo]]<ref name="ep27">{{episode|Yu-Gi-Oh! ARC-V|27|ref}}</ref>
* [[Nagi]]<ref name="ep27" />
* [[Taka (ARC-V)|Taka]]<ref name="ep27" />

'''"Third Time's A Charm"''', known as '''"Start of the New Semester! Troubling Premonition"''' in the Japanese version, is the one hundred and fifth episode of the ''[[Yu-Gi-Oh! GX]]'' anime. It first aired in Japan on October 4, 2006, and in the US on April 7, 2007.

{{Episode summary|[[Jaden Yuki]] recalls the events of the previous two years.}}

==Summary==
This episode features no Duels, and serves as a recap of Seasons 2. At the end of the episode, [[Chancellor Sheppard]] remarks how much [[Jaden Yuki]] has grown during the last two years, and believes that [[Thelonious Viper]] will be able to help him release his true abilities.

==Trivia==
* When [[Jaden Yuki|Jaden]] says to [[Tyranno Hassleberry|Hassleberry]] that Neos thanks him for his help, Hassleberry thinks Jaden is crazy and replies with some ununderstandable words, which he explains to Syrus that it's a supposed alien language, he makes the 'Live Long and Prosper' gesture used by Spock from Star Trek.

==Errors==
* In the dub, Hassleberry was surprised to see Blair; however, he hadn't met her before that point. In the original, he asked Chazz who she was.

==Featured cards==
All cards featured in this episode are from flashbacks.

[[File:Maiami City.png|thumb|right|300px|Paradise City]]
'''Paradise City''', known as '''Maiami City''' or '''Miami City'''<ref name="ep2">{{episode|Yu-Gi-Oh! ARC-V|2|ref}}</ref><ref name="ep8">{{episode|Yu-Gi-Oh! ARC-V|8|ref}}</ref> ({{Ruby|舞網|まいあみ}}{{Ruby|市|し}} ''Maiami-shi'') in the Japanese anime version and, in the manga, as '''Maiami City''' ({{Ruby|ＭＡＩＡＭＩ|マイアミ}}{{Ruby|市|し}} ''Maiami-shi''), is a city set on the coast of Japan, where the central events of the first two arcs of the ''[[Yu-Gi-Oh! ARC-V]]'' anime take place. The development of the city's technology is focused on [[Duel]]ing. The headquarters of the [[Leo Corporation]] is located here, along with preparatory Duel schools such as the [[You Show Duel School]] and [[Leo Institute of Dueling]].<ref name="orgvjump">{{cite web|url=http://www.ygorganization.com/ocg-v-jump-time/|title=OCG V-Jump Time|publisher=YGOrganization|date=February 17, 2014}}</ref>
Paradise City is the home to the Leo Corporation's [[ARC System]] that gave birth to [[Action Duel]]s, which started here and is now popular across the world.<ref name="orgvjump" /> [[Yuto]] later reveals that Paradise City is located in the [[Standard Dimension]], a dimension of unknown origins where [[Ritual Summon|Ritual]], [[Fusion Summon|Fusion]], [[Synchro Summon|Synchro]], and [[Xyz Summon]]ing all exist, as well as where the [[Pendulum Summon]] originated.

==Trivia==
* The city's name in the Japanese version is a pun on [[wikipedia:Miami|Miami]], a famous United States city in the real world.
** In the English version, the name Paradise - given later events in the anime - may suggest a reference to Milton's ''[[wikipedia:Paradise Lost|Paradise Lost]]''.

pages.title: Card Trivia:Magellanica, the Deep Sea City

revisions.content:
{{Navigation}}

* "[[Deep Sea Prima Donna]]" and "[[Deep Sea Minstrel]]" appear in this card's artwork.

* The city in this card's artwork appears in the background of "[[Deep Sea Repetiteur]]".

* This card is based on ''Magellanica'' (other name for ''[[wikipedia:Terra Australis|Terra Australis]]''), a hypothetical continent which appeared on maps between the 15th and 18th centuries.
